title: 103_s2266
content:
Section 2805 of the Recreation Management Act of 1992 is amended by adding the following: 
- Penalty: Any person who violates any regulation issued under subsection (a)(2) shall be fined in accordance with Title 18, United States Code, or imprisoned not more than 6 months, or both, and may be adjudged to pay all costs of the proceedings.
- Law Enforcement Officers: Bureau of Reclamation law enforcement officers have additional authorities. The Secretary of the Interior is authorized to designate officers or employees to maintain law and order and protect persons and property within areas under the jurisdiction of the Bureau of Reclamation. In performing such duties, the designated officers or employees may have certain powers. Designated officers or employees may carry firearms and make arrests without warrant for any offense against the United States committed in their presence, or for any felony recognizable under the laws of the United States if they have reasonable grounds to believe the person to be arrested has committed or is committing such a felony. Such arrests occur within areas of jurisdiction designated by the Secretary of the Interior. Designated officers or employees may execute any warrant or process issued by a court or officer of competent jurisdiction for the enforcement of federal laws or regulations arising out of an offense committed in a Bureau of Reclamation project or where jurisdiction is designated by the Secretary of the Interior. The curr_chunk discusses the conduct of investigations into offenses committed within the jurisdiction of the Bureau of Reclamation in the absence of investigation by other federal law enforcement agencies. The curr_chunk discusses the jurisdiction over offenses committed with the concurrence of other agencies. Special police officers designated by the Secretary may include officers from other federal agencies or law enforcement personnel from states or political subdivisions. The curr_chunk discusses the cooperation between the Bureau of Reclamation and other agencies or political subdivisions for law enforcement in areas under their jurisdiction. The curr_chunk discusses the limited reimbursement provided to a State or its political subdivisions for law enforcement in areas where the State has ceded concurrent legislative jurisdiction over the affected area of the Bureau of Reclamation system. The Bureau of Reclamation system provides limited reimbursement to States or political subdivisions for law enforcement activities within its projects, as specified by the Secretary of the Interior. Special rules apply to designated officers, unless otherwise provided in this subsection. In this subsection, a law enforcement officer designated to act as a special police under paragraph (2) shall not be considered a Federal employee and is not subject to laws relating to Federal employment, including those related to hours of work, rates of compensation, leave, unemployment compensation. For the purposes of the tort claim provisions of Title 28, United States Code, a law enforcement officer acting as a special police under paragraph (2) shall be considered a Federal employee. For purposes of subchapter I of chapter 81 of title 5, United States Code, unemployment compensation and Federal benefits apply. The Title 5, United States Code, relates to compensation for Federal employees for work injuries. A law enforcement officer of any State or political subdivision acting as a special policeman under paragraph (2) is deemed to be a civil service employee of the United States within the meaning of the term 'employee' as defined in section 8101 of Title 5, United States Code. The United States Code provisions apply to the authorities provided in this subsection, supplementing the law enforcement responsibilities of the Bureau of Reclamation without authorizing delegation of enforcement responsibilities to state and local governments. Regulations concerning other activities are overseen by the Secretary through the Commissioner. The Commissioner enforces regulations issued under subsection (a)(2) regarding boating and activities on or relating to waters within areas of the Bureau of Reclamation's jurisdiction. Nothing in this title limits the investigative jurisdiction of any Federal law enforcement agency other than the Bureau of Reclamation. The Recreation Management Act of 1992 is amended to include penalties for violating regulations issued under subsection (a)(2), with fines or imprisonment up to 6 months. Bureau of Reclamation law enforcement officers are granted additional authorities. The Secretary of the Interior can designate officers or employees to maintain law and order within Bureau of Reclamation areas. These designated individuals can carry firearms, make arrests without warrants for offenses committed in their presence, or for felonies with reasonable grounds to believe the person has committed or is committing the crime. The designated officers or employees within Bureau of Reclamation areas can carry firearms, make arrests without warrants for offenses committed in their presence, or for felonies with reasonable grounds to believe the person has committed or is committing the crime. They can also execute warrants issued by a court for the enforcement of Federal laws in Reclamation project areas and conduct investigations of offenses. The Bureau of Reclamation officers can investigate offenses against the United States within their jurisdiction, cooperate with states in law enforcement, and perform other specified law enforcement duties as directed by the Secretary of the Interior. Special officers designated by the Secretary can also carry out similar law enforcement responsibilities. The Secretary of the Interior can designate officers from other agencies or states as special officers in Bureau of Reclamation areas when additional law enforcement personnel are needed. Limited reimbursement may be provided to states or their subdivisions for ceding jurisdiction over affected areas. The Secretary of the Interior can designate officers from other agencies or states as special officers in Bureau of Reclamation areas. Law enforcement officers designated as special officers are not considered Federal employees and are not subject to Federal employment laws. Law enforcement officers from any State or political subdivision can be considered Federal employees for tort claim provisions and compensation benefits under certain circumstances. The provisions of this subsection supplement the law enforcement responsibilities of the Bureau of Reclamation without allowing the delegation of such responsibilities to State and local governments. The jurisdiction of Federal law enforcement agencies, other than the Bureau of Reclamation, remains unaffected, and States retain their civil and criminal jurisdiction within Bureau of Reclamation projects.
